docs.lead_paragraph: With Independence Day just passed, a good nationalist shouldn’t be afraid to ask who lives better, us or them?

headline.main: A National Gut-Check: Who Lives Better?
headline.print_headline: A National Gut-Check: Who Lives Better?

docs.snippet: With Independence Day just passed, a good nationalist shouldn’t be afraid to ask who lives better, us or them?

docs.lead_paragraph: One of the memorable scenes in ''Sicko,'' Michael Moore's latest cinematic provocation, comes from France, where he shows doctors in their little white cars making house calls -- for free. But it's not just France. When we lived in Italy some time ago, a doctor came to our farmhouse rental on Easter Sunday morning to diagnose a stomach ailment. He charged nothing.

headline.main: A National Gut-Check: Who Lives Better?

docs.abstract: Guest Op-Ed columnist Timothy Egan compares health care in Italy and United States; holds that United States may have worst of all systems that allows handful of corporations to make insurance decisions, with incentive to deny coverage; says it is not surprising that US ranks 37th in health care effectiveness and Italy, where poor receive free care, ranks second (M)
docs.snippet: One of the memorable scenes in ''Sicko,'' Michael Moore's latest cinematic provocation, comes from France, where he shows doctors in their little white cars making house calls -- for free.      But it's not just France. When we lived in Italy some...

docs.lead_paragraph: What are the career aspirations of the nation's most accomplished and ambitious students these days? I haven't seen a formal survey, but a rapidly growing percentage of the best students I teach say they want to manage hedge funds or private equity firms. Little wonder. According to Institutional Investor's Alpha magazine, the hedge fund manager James Simons earned $1.7 billion last year, and two other managers earned more than $1 billion. The combined income of the top 25 hedge fund managers exceeded $14 billion in 2006.

headline.main: A Career in Hedge Funds and the Price of Overcrowding

docs.abstract: Robert H Frank Economic Scene column on many college graduates who want career as hedge fund manager; says sending ever larger numbers of most talented graduates out to prospect for deals has high opportunity cost, yet adds little economic value; holds by making after-tax rewards in investment industry little less spectacular, proposed legislation would raise attractiveness of other career paths, ones in which extra talent would yield substantial gains (M)
